thread.title: Texas 6, Detroit 2: Tigers' Boyd roughed up by Rangers
thread.title_full: Texas 6, Detroit 2: Tigers' Boyd roughed up by Rangers

title: Texas 6, Detroit 2: Tigers' Boyd roughed up by Rangers
text:
Texas 6, Detroit 2: Tigers' Boyd roughed up by Rangers J.D. Martinez went 3-for-4 and Rajai Davis, Ian Kinsler and Nick Castellanos each had two hits. Post to Facebook Texas 6, Detroit 2: Tigers' Boyd roughed up by Rangers J.D. Martinez went 3-for-4 and Rajai Davis, Ian Kinsler and Nick Castellanos each had two hits. Check out this story on WZZM13.com: http://on.freep.com/1FCYfB3 Cancel Send A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. 25 To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs Texas 6, Detroit 2: Tigers' Boyd roughed up by Rangers Detroit Free Press 11:37 p.m. EDT September 30, 2015 In this week's episode, Anthony Fenech and Drew Sharp discuss Brad Ausmus' return in 2016, why Daniel Norris threw so much in Tuesday's first inning and more Detroit Tigers issues. Subscribe to Talkin' Tigers in iTunes, too! Tigers rightfielder Tyler Collins hits a two-run single in the first inning Wednesday in Arlington, Texas. (Photo: Ronald Martinez Getty Images) 10 CONNECT 1 TWEET LINKEDIN 25 COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
ARLINGTON, Texas – Tuedsay night, it was Daniel Norris. 
Tonight, it was the other left-handed starting pitcher the Tigers acquired at the trade deadline for Blue Jays' ace David Price. 
Like Norris, it was Matt Boyd who was beat up, tagged for a lot of runs in a little time in the Tigers' 6-2 loss to the Rangers at Globe Life Park. 
In 2 2/3 innings, Boyd allowed six runs – all earned – on seven hits. He walked one, struck out two and allowed three home runs. 
The first was to Adrian Beltre. It was a two-run shot to leftfield. 
The second was to Robinson Chirinos. It was a solo shot to left-centerfield. 
The third was to Mike Napoli, a two-run shot to leftfield and one batter later, after a Mitch Moreland single, Boyd's night was no more after 69 pitches. 
Like Tuesday night, the Tigers took a two-run lead in the top of the first inning, when Tyler Collins hit a two-run single. 
They were the only runs the Tigers would plate, as Rangers right-hander Yovani Gallardo settled from there, allowing nine hits over 5 1/3 innings. He struck out five and walked one. 
The Tigers out-hit the Rangers, 12-9, but could not muster a run on two hits in 3 2/3 innings against their bullpen. 
J.D. Martinez went 3-for-4 and Rajai Davis, Ian Kinsler and Nick Castellanos each had two hits. 
With the win, the Rangers' magic number in the American League West fell to two. With the loss, the Tigers remain in last place in the Central. 
Contact Anthony Fenech: afenech@freepress.com . Follow him on Twitter @anthonyfenech . Check out our latest Tigers podcast at freep.com/tigerspodcast or on iTunes.
